thread.title: Road rage gunman takes aim at driver trying to merge onto LBJ Freeway
thread.title_full: Road rage gunman takes aim at driver trying to merge onto LBJ Freeway

author: Eline de Bruijn
title: Road rage gunman takes aim at driver trying to merge onto LBJ Freeway
text:
(Rose Baca/The Dallas Morning News) Road rage gunman takes aim at driver trying to merge onto LBJ Freeway Filed under Crime at Get Daily Dallas News Headlines Sign Up Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
A Garland driver was shaken but unhurt Wednesday in a road rage shooting while trying to merge onto LBJ Freeway. 
"I was just shot at," the man, who feared for his safety and asked not to be named, later said in a text to his wife. "I'm still kind of shaken and have mixed emotions: anger, disbelief, shock." 
The victim had just dropped off his child at school and was trying to merge onto the westbound highway near Skillman Street about 7:30 a.m. when the ramp narrowed and a driver in a white GMC Yukon XL refused to let him merge. The gunman peppered the victim's pickup with bullets. (Facebook) 
As the ramp ended, the man heard two shots. He tried to get away on LBJ, but the Yukon passed him on the driver's side, pulled in front of his pickup and then slowed down on his passenger side. That's when the gunman fired twice more. 
The victim could feel the bullets tear into his pickup but was unharmed. He pulled over and called 911 as the shooter exited LBJ onto Central Expressway. 
He got out and found large-caliber bullets rolling around in the bed of his pickup, along with four bullet holes: three in the bed and once in the back of the cab. 
"I could understand road rage, but never to the point of pulling out a gun," the driver said. "That's a whole other level." 
He didn't get a look at the licence plate and couldn't give a detailed description of the shooter, but suspects other drivers witnessed the shooting. 
So far no arrests have been, but Dallas police are investigating. Anyone with information can contact police at 214-670-5840. View Comments
